newsitem.title: USA: U.S. meat group steps up beef promotions in Mexico.
newsitem.headline: U.S. meat group steps up beef promotions in Mexico.

text.p: Several Mexican supermarket chains have devoted special sections in their stores to selling U.S. beef, and the effort should contribute to a nearly 10 percent increase in beef sales to that country, the U.S. Meat Export Federation (USMEF) said.

The USMEF, with funding from the U.S. Agriculture Department and the beef checkoff program, has installed U.S. beef sections in Gigante stores in Tijuana and in Soriana stores in Monterrey. Gigante plans to add the sections this November in its Mexico City stores, as does Wal-Mart.
Bruce Cobb, director of the USMEF's Mexico City's office, said the U.S. meat sections are unique in Mexico and will be maintained by a staff trained in promoting U.S. beef.
"As the economy in Mexico continues to recover, meat consumption is up and interest in the program is very high on the Mexican side," Cobb said.

Mexico is the fourth largest export market for U.S. beef with 1996 sales expected to top 60,000 tonnes versus 1995 sales of 54,712 tonnes. Sales from January to July this year were up 38 percent from a year ago at 44,774, the USMEF said.
The USMEF has a goal of exporting 167,000 tonnes to Mexico in the year 2000.
